Review this field to determine if any equipment types should be considered `Things`.

Keep in mind, a Thing is the physical platform that hosts the sensors, while a Sensor is the specific instrument or method that performs the measurement.

A Thing is the "what" or "where" (e.g., the weather station), and a Sensor is the "how" (e.g., the barometer attached to the station).

AI suggests creating a separate `Deployment` or `Installation` table to store this information. The logic is that this information does not belong in the Thing, Sensor, or Sample tables. These measurements describe the relationship between a specific Thing and a specific Sensor over a period of time.

Not necessary to preserve this field. We can determine if a continuous water level measurement has been collected from a Thing by querying the Observation table for water level measurements.

Not necessary to preserve this field. We can determine if water quality data has been collected from a Thing by querying the Observation table for a specific parameter or observed property.

Not necessary to preserve this field. We can determine if stream flow or spring discharge data has been collected from a Thing by querying the Observation table for a specific parameter or observed property.
Not necessary to preserve this field. We can determine if pump test data exist for a Thing by querying the Observation table for parameters or observed properties associated with pump tests.

The values in the `Location.Geometry` field from NMAquifer will be used to migrate X,Y,Z information into Ocotillo. The Geometry values were chosen instead of the Easting values because every record has a Geometry value and that value is already in WGS84, the CRS of choice for Ocotillo.

The values in the `Location.Geometry` field from NMAquifer will be used to migrate X,Y,Z information into Ocotillo. The Geometry values were chosen instead of the UTM datum values because every record has a Geometry value and that value is already in WGS84, the CRS of choice for Ocotillo.

Note that in Ocotillo, `well_use` is different from `well_type`.  The `well_use` field describes the purpose or function of the well. It answers the question of why the well was constructed and what it is used for (Monitoring, Irrigation, Livestock, etc).

The `well_type` field describes the physical construction and design of the well. It answers the question of how the well is built. Examples of well type include Dug, Artesian, Drilled.
